sections.title: What is Machine Learning?
sections.content: Machine Learning (ML) is a subset of Artificial Intelligence that enables computers to learn and make decisions from data without being explicitly programmed for every task. Think of it as teaching a computer to recognize patterns, just like how you learned to recognize different animals by seeing many examples.

examples.title: Email Spam Detection
examples.description: ML algorithms analyze thousands of emails to learn patterns that distinguish spam from legitimate emails

sections.title: Types of Machine Learning
sections.content: There are three main types of machine learning: Supervised Learning (learning with examples and correct answers), Unsupervised Learning (finding hidden patterns in data), and Reinforcement Learning (learning through trial and error with rewards).

examples.title: Supervised Learning - Image Classification
examples.description: Training a model to recognize cats vs dogs using labeled images
examples.code:
# Supervised learning example
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier

# Split data into training and testing
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(features, labels, test_size=0.2)

# Train the model
model = RandomForestClassifier()
model.fit(X_train, y_train)

# Make predictions
predictions = model.predict(X_test)

examples.title: Unsupervised Learning - Customer Segmentation
examples.description: Grouping customers based on purchasing behavior without predefined categories
examples.code:
# Unsupervised learning example
from sklearn.cluster import KMeans
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Cluster customers into groups
kmeans = KMeans(n_clusters=3)
customer_groups = kmeans.fit_predict(customer_data)

# Visualize clusters
plt.scatter(customer_data[:, 0], customer_data[:, 1], c=customer_groups)
plt.title('Customer Segments')
plt.show()

sections.title: Building Your First ML Model
sections.content: Let's create a simple machine learning model to predict student performance based on study hours and previous grades. This hands-on approach will help you understand the ML workflow: data preparation, model training, and evaluation.

examples.title: Student Performance Predictor
examples.description: Predict final exam scores based on study hours and attendance
examples.code:
import pandas as pd
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error

# Sample student data
data = {
    'study_hours': [2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 3, 5, 7, 9, 1],
    'attendance': [60, 80, 90, 95, 98, 70, 85, 92, 96, 50],
    'final_score': [65, 75, 85, 90, 95, 70, 80, 88, 93, 55]
}

df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Prepare features and target
X = df[['study_hours', 'attendance']]
y = df['final_score']

# Train the model
model = LinearRegression()
model.fit(X, y)

# Make a prediction for a new student
new_student = [[6, 85]]  # 6 hours study, 85% attendance
predicted_score = model.predict(new_student)
print(f'Predicted final score: {predicted_score[0]:.1f}')

sections.title: AI Ethics and Responsible Development
sections.content: As future AI developers and users, it's crucial to understand the ethical implications of AI systems. This includes issues of bias, privacy, transparency, and the impact of AI on society and employment.

examples.title: Bias in AI Systems
examples.description: Understanding how biased training data can lead to unfair AI decisions
examples.code:
# Example of checking for bias in data
import pandas as pd

# Analyze hiring data for potential bias
hiring_data = pd.read_csv('hiring_decisions.csv')

# Check gender distribution in successful hires
gender_success_rate = hiring_data.groupby('gender')['hired'].mean()
print('Success rate by gender:')
print(gender_success_rate)

# This analysis helps identify potential bias in hiring algorithms
